title: Melbourne cycling stress
story: Measures of Level of Traffic Stress aim to categorise streets based on their comfort and safety for cycling. Identifying street segments of high stress and exploring the underlying measures or indicators contributing to the classifcation can help to inform priorities for investment. This map depicts levels of traffic stress for Melbourne, Australia, according to two classification standards: one tailored for the Victorian policy context based and another using traffic stress classification based on UK policy, allowing for comparisons between the two approaches.

params.directions: Select a road segment to view a range of metrics related to suitability for walking and cycling.
params.help:
Level of Traffic Stress (LTS) for cycling along discrete road segments has been measured specifically for the Victorian policy context. The classification ranges from 1 (lowest stress, for use by all cyclists) to 4 (most stressful, and least suitable for safe cycling). Our implementation of this measure draws on research developed at RMIT by Dr Afshin Jafari and Steve Pemberton (read more).

Multiple variables may contribute to comfort or stress when cycling, including traffic intensity, intersection design, and presence of separated bike paths. However, environmental aspects such as greenery and shade are also factors influencing cycling choices.

Pemberton, S., & Jafari, A. (2024). Cycling safety and comfort (v1.0.1). Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.13831295

legend.title: Low stress, for use by all cyclists
High stress, least suitable for safe cycling

title: Service provision for 20 minute neighbourhoods
story: How well served are people living near activity centres? Activity Centres are commercially-zoned areas that could, potentially, form the basis of 20 minute neighbourhoods.  How far are they along the track?  That is, which activity centres meet a target of 80% of people being within walking distance of the relevant destination types?

params.directions: Use the drop down selection menu on the left hand side to select an amenity or service and view the spatial distribution of access for activity centre populations.  Select an activity centre to view a plot of the percentage of people within that living within walking distance of different kinds of amenities and services.
params.help:
How well served are people living near activity centres? Activity Centres are commercially-zoned areas that could, potentially, form the basis of 20 minute neighbourhoods. How far are they along the track? That is, which activity centres meet a target of 80% of people being within walking distance of the relevant destination types?. This scenario is based on analysis led by Steve Pemberton through the JIBE project. Read more.

Pemberton, S., Saghapour, T., Giles-Corti, B., Abdollahyar, M., Both, A., Pearson, D., Higgs, C., Jafari, A., Singh, D., Gunn, L., Woodcock, J., & Zapata-Diomedi, B. (2024). 20-minute neighbourhood scenario modelling for Melbourne (JIBE) (Version 1.0.0). https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.13846250

focus.selection_description: Percentage of activity centre population within recommended walking distance of...

overlays.id: Proposed development to achieve 20 minute neighbourhoods of 80% activity centre population access.  Zoom to view potential locations in candidate 'low access' areas.

hints.hint: Click legend values to filter the map, and click again to reset.

title: Melbourne accessibility
story: How well connected are Melbourne's Local Government Areas (LGAs) to a range of destinations by walking and cycling?  This scenario is based on analysis led by Steve Pemberton through the JIBE project.

params.directions: Use the drop down selection menu on the left hand side to select mode and scenario to view accessibility scores for Melbourne's LGAs.  Select an LGA to view a plot of access scores by mode and scenario.
params.help:
How well connected are Melbourne's Local Government Areas (LGAs) to a range of destinations by walking and cycling? This scenario is based on analysis led by Steve Pemberton through the JIBE project. Read more.

Pemberton, S., Saghapour, T., Giles-Corti, B., Abdollahyar, M., Both, A., Pearson, D., Higgs, C., Jafari, A., Singh, D., Gunn, L., Woodcock, J., & Zapata-Diomedi, B. (2024). 20-minute neighbourhood scenario modelling for Melbourne (JIBE) (Version 1.0.0). https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.13846250

focus.selection_description: Access to a range of destinations by walking or cycling

title: Melbourne transport exposures and health
story: Urban inequities in health outcomes are often linked to social and environmental factors.  As background context, this scenario provides the distribution of relative disadvantage in Melbourne, Australia, based on the SEIFA Index of Relative Socio-economic Disadvantage (IRSD).  IRSD combines information on income, employment, education, health, crime, and living environment.  Clicking on an area allows exploration of the impacts of a cycling intervention on a range of environmental, behavioural and health outcomes.

params.directions: Click on an area to explore the impacts of reduced traffic speed and improved cycling infrastructure on a range of environmental, behavioural and health outcomes.
params.help: Urban inequities in health outcomes are often linked to social and environmental factors. This vignette focused on Manchester, UK, features scenarios modelled through the JIBE Project. As background context, the distribution of relative disadvantage, drawing on the Index of Multiple Deprivation (IMD) 2019. The IMD is a composite measure of relative deprivation at the small area level, combining information on income, employment, education, health, crime, and living environment.

dictionary.IMD19: Index of Relative Socio-economic Disadvantage (2016; Deciles)

pm25.title: PM2.5 air pollution (µg/m³)
pm25.threshold_description: The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends an annual mean exposure of 10 µg/m³ for fine particulate matter (PM2.5).  See WHO (2024) for more information.

no2.title: NO2 air pollution (µg/m³)
no2.threshold_description: The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends an annual mean exposure of 40 µg/m³ for nitrogen dioxide (NO₂).  See WHO (2024) for more information.

mmethr.title: Marginal metabolic equivalent (MET) physical activity (hours/week)
mmethr.threshold_description: Marginal metabolic equivalent (mMETs) is used to measure energy expenditure or physical activity intensity in health and fitness assessments. The recommended 150 min/week of moderate-to-vigorous aerobic physical activity is approximately equivalent to 8.75 mMET-hours per week.  See Garcia et al. (2023) for more information.

dictionary.mmethr_walk: Average metabolic equivalent (MET) physical activity (hours/week; Walking)
dictionary.mmethr_cycle: Average metabolic equivalent (MET) physical activity (hours/week; Cycling)

hints.hint: Click legend values to filter the map, and click again to reset.

View the distribution of relative disadvantage (2019) for LAD or MSOA areas, or click on an area to explore the impacts of a cycling intervention on a range of environmental, behavioural and health outcomes.

title: Manchester cycling stress
story: How would reduced traffic speed and improved cycling infrastructure impact travel behaviour and health? In the scenario, we restricted speeds to 20mph on minor roads and introduced offroad cycling infrastructure alongside major roads. Changes such as these are expected to shift transport choices from private car towards sustainable modes, leading to health benefits in the broader population from reduced pollutant inhalation and increased physical activity.

params.directions: Traffic stress estimates for cycling are displayed for streets in Greater Manchester, UK.  While stress was evaluated in each traffic direction, only the maximum stress in either direction is displayed for any street segment.  The classification ranges from 1 (lowest stress, for use by all cyclists) to 4 (most stressful, and least suitable for safe cycling). shown for Manchester, UK.  Select a road segment to view simulated weekday traffic counts for cyclists, pedestrians, cars, and trucks in the reference scenario.
params.help:
How would reduced traffic speed and improved cycling infrastructure impact travel behaviour and health? In the scenario, we restricted speeds to 20mph on minor roads and introduced offroad cycling infrastructure alongside major roads. Changes such as these are expected to shift transport choices from private car towards sustainable modes, leading to health benefits in the broader population from reduced pollutant inhalation and increased physical activity.

Read more:

Labib, S. M., Itova, I., Staves, C., Zapata-Diomedi et al. (2022). Integrating spatially detailed micro-environmental attributes to a routable transport network for active travel modeling: A pilot study in Greater Manchester. GISRUK, Liverpool, United Kingdom. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.6411627

Zhang, Q., Staves, C., Saadi, I. et al. (2024). Heterogeneity in the effects of built environment on walking and cycling behavior. 17th International Conference on Travel Behavior Research. https://doi.org/10.17863/CAM.107588

Staves, C., Zhang, Q., Moeckel, R. et al. (2024). A Dynamic Least-Cost Path Method for Incorporating the Street-level Built Environment into Mode Choice Utility. 12th Symposium of the European Association for Research in Transportation. https://doi.org/10.17863/CAM.107573

Manchester.attribution: UK Office for National Statistics LSOA 2021/2011, IMD2019, MSOA, LAD, Ordnance Survey Boundary-Line™

layers.dictionary_notes: ¹ Counts are estimated for street segments using simulation modelling for a typical weekday and presented here as total traffic in both directions in the reference scenario.

focus.reference_description: Modelled reference stress levels for Manchester, 2018
focus.scenario_description: Reduced traffic speeds and improved cycling infrastructure
focus.scenario_directions: Interactive exploration of upstream exposures and downstream outcomes for scenarios will be added in a future update. Analysis considered bi-directional stress, however only the highest stress rating in either direction was visualised for each street segment.

title: Melbourne mode shift analysis
story: Comparison of travel behavior and health outcomes between baseline and cycling intervention scenarios for Melbourne, Australia. Explore mode share, physical activity, and demographic patterns.
